p: For scope 3 emissions3, SBTi’s target-setting requirements are less rigid, recognizing that companies are less able to accurately quantify and influence scope 3 emissions [27]. Companies must set SBTs for scope 3 emissions if they account for at least 40% of total scope 1, 2, and 3 emissions (which is often the case), and the targets must cover at least two-thirds of scope 3 emissions [27]. Companies can use target-setting methods other than the ACA and SDA methods (subject to certain constraints), and scope 3 targets are still allowed to align with a 2 °C scenario in addition to the well-below 2 °C or 1.5 °C scenarios. Companies may also set supplier or customer engagement targets instead of direct scope 3 emission reduction targets. With engagement targets, companies commit to motivating selected suppliers and customers to set SBTs for their scope 1 and 2 emissions.
